awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mathematical and computational methods for stochastic systems in nonlinear optics
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this collaborative research project is to develop methods for analysis, modeling, and computation for stochastic partial differential equations arising in nonlinear optics. The study of noise in these systems is complicated by several factors. In particular:
(i) the complexity due to the interplay of many physical effects,
(ii) the presence of multiple length and time scales, and
(iii) the fact that the critical events that represent system failures are, by design, extremely rare.  We will address these challenges by (a) creating a set of analytical methods to obtain reductions from the stochastic partial differential equations that govern the system's behavior to a set of low-dimensional stochastic differential equations;
(b) developing efficient methods for the study of noise across multiple time and space scales; and (c) implementing hybrid analytical-computational methods that can efficiently target the rare events of interest and ultimately estimate the reliability of these systems.

Lightwave systems have a wide range of applications, in particular as lasers and optical communication lines, and their emergence has had a dramatic impact on our lives over the last fifty years. Lasers are used at low powers in applications related to scanning and communications; at higher powers they are employed in surgical and industrial applications. As noise is a major limiting factor in optical systems, further technological progress will depend critically on understanding the impact of noise and on being able to control noise-induced system failures. This research will provide new analytical and computational tools that support the analysis and design of the next generation of optical devices.

por.por_cntn:
Prof. Richard Moore has completed a study of the impact of noise in
optical systems, specifically in mode-locked laser models, using
analytical techniques and computational tools taken from the
mathematical study of large deviations in dynamical systems with
small noise strength. The physical importance of this study lies in
its demonstration that, when quantifying how noise affects a
physical system, it is often important to consider not only how
small fluctuations dictate near-equilibrium variations of the
system's state (e.g., the linewidth of an output laser line) but
also how rare combinations of noise increments can accumulate to
produce critical events such as phase slips that foil a laser's
feedback mechanism. This is a particularly vital phenomenon in
modern lasers used for precision timekeeping, a technology
essential to proposals for the redefinition of the basic definition
of the second, and for control of ultrafast chemical experiments,
since these lasers require sensitive feedback to produce
pulses of light with carefully controlled optical phases.

The intellectual merit of this study lies in the fact that recently
developed numerical tools for the computation of minimizers of the
action functional relevant to understanding the probability of
large deviations in dynamical systems have seen relatively little
deployment in applied physical systems, and virtually none in
optical systems. Prof. Moore has used these tools to develop a
numerical code for the computation of these minimizers in the
context of pulsed optical systems arising in communications and
laser settings, and has shown that the paths computed from
finite-dimensional reductions of the full dynamical systems being
studied can be used to inform importance-sampled Monte Carlo
simulations in the full system. This technique reduces the
computational cost of computing rare events in high-dimensional
stochastic dynamical systems by several orders of magnitude. Prof.
Moore has also demonstrated how the results of these simulations
can be used to improve the low-order reduced system, which can
again be used to inform importance-sampled Monte Carlo simulations
in an iterative way.

The broader impacts of the study lie primarily in the fact that the
methodology used can be applied to a variety of systems of
interest. The importance of the action associated with large
deviations as a measure of distance between states in a stochastic
system is being realized in a number of different fields ranging
from materials science to neuroscience. Recent work uses this
action for the purpose of observing which experimentally
controllable parameters should be varied in order to induce
structural bifurcations in large systems of stochastic differential
equations occuring in genetic networks. Other applications specific to wave equations include the exploration of instantons, or noise paths leading to steep
gradients in the solution of stochastic wave equations, in an
effort to understand intermittency related to turbulence. Other
broader impacts include the use of this grant material in the
training of two doctoral students. The first, Dr. Daniel Cargill,
graduated in 2012 and is now research staff at the Air Force
Research Laboratory. The second, Mr. YiMing Yu, has just begun his
third year of graduate study, having passed his qualifying exam in
the summer of 2015. A final broader impact involves the application
of methods learned in this study to a new project developed by

autonomous vehicles for the purpose of assimilating velocity fields
